messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: learning to read Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: They are called furigana and are there to show the phonetic pronunciation of the kanji. Barry Thomas. ... From: bungotakadasword  To:
messages.messageBody:
They are called "furigana" and are there to show the phonetic pronunciation of
the kanji.

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "bungotakadasword" <MuramasaIII@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, August 16, 2005 2:02 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: learning to read Japanese


On another sword list.........." since "§ can be read as sukashi,
why does ,µ appear at the end of the third group? If it supplies the
shi of sukashi, isn't it redundant? "



I believe that's because not all Japanese are that well verse in
Kanji.....it was put there to help with the pronunciation/meaning.
This is quite common when " complicated " kanji are involved.
You see that quite often in woodblock prints (e.g. those fancy names of
the Kuniyoshi's 47 ronins prints series ).

Just my opinion/observation ( could be often wrong )...........


milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read JapaneseYes.  I m having two problems: First, some kanji just don t show up in those dictionaries, period, and some like
messages.messageBody:
Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read JapaneseYes. I'm having two problems:

First, some kanji just don't show up in those dictionaries, period, and some like the middle one in the fifth group don't even seem to offer an indexed element to use to look them up.

Second, some hiragana ?particles? don't appear in my particle book.


Treating line two as five groups of characters, I got:


1 tettsu "iron" ji "surface"



2 ??? wa ri "?dust?"



3 ji-sukashi shi "?and so?",



4 ??? shu? wa



5 Kin / Kon / Kane "gold" ??? Kan / ha "inlay"





----- Original Message -----
From: tom helm
To: David Zincavage
Cc: token_kenkyu_kai@...
Sent: Sunday, August 14, 2005 5:51 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read Japanese


David-
When you say "that second line", are we still talking about the page from the Bushu Ito book?
-t

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read Japanese
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: Please excuse the foolish reply. Mon refers to lineage and I believe, and that the connection is closer than Den or tradition, a student teacher
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
Please excuse the foolish reply. "Mon" refers to lineage and I believe, and that the connection is closer than "Den" or tradition, a student teacher relationship. Again I could be off base, but it seems that while the tsuba is indeed Bushu, which covers quite a range of motif, the Ito characteristic of wire cutting certainly isn't there.
AF

>>> jdz@... 08/14/05 1:29 PM >>>
Sorry, I expressed my self unclearly. I was having difficulty with the "Nidai Masatsune Mon" section of the upper line text in parenthesis. I was too dumb to put ni + dai together, and I rejected Masa for some reason, and found myself another theory. And I did not understand that "mon" meant "pupil."

David
----- Original Message -----
From: arnold frenzel
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, August 14, 2005 10:09 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] learning to read Japanese


Bushu ju Masatomo I think. AF

>>> jdz@... 08/14/05 2:48 AM >>>
Bottom right tsuba picture from Bushu Ito book, the top line, the part at the right in parenthesis, I think, is a date reference.

I get:

(5) 1. ni "second" 2. dai/tai "era" 3.sei/sho "right, justice" 4. ko/tsuni(ne) "always, fixed, constant" 5. mon "gate"



What's it supposed to come out as? How should I be reading this?

http://zincavage.org/MasatomoAoi.html

I did get all the stuff to the left on the top line:

Aoi leaf design tsuba -- Mei -- Bushu ju -- Masafusa

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
